captions.text: Currently, it's 6AM, and my loyal students have been waiting here
since a crazy hour like 5AM or more, something crazy.
Why are they here?  They're here to cheer on the 3rd year students
because today is their SAT day.  Uhhh!  And we're competing with another school
for cheering, but our team will win for sure.
So why are my students here at 6AM cheering?
Well, this isn't just any normal exam.
This is the 3rd year SAT exam to get into university,
and I'm not kidding when I say that my students from 3rd year
have been like training for this their whole lives,
and 3rd year high school is just about them staying and studying for this exam.
So this exam is a really, really big deal.

comments.text: May I know which school is this?﻿
comments.author: Andromeda Maghen Bellerose

comments.text:
I'm in year 11 ( England ), I should be doing my copious amounts of 
revision for my exams right now :/﻿
comments.author: CaitlinIsANinja x

comments.text: I'll just study the day before, no big deal.....Sh*t!!!!!﻿
comments.author: TwoLargePizzas

comments.text:
Another exam day. There should be chances before graduation to take the 
test than end of senior year. And held more than one day each year. What if 
you are sick? You have to wait anothe entire year? The main problem is the 
perceived lack of worth in jobs that are not professional. I understand the 
idea of being tutored but I do not understand hagwons. How is sitting in 
yet another math class and sleeping through public school math class 
helpful? You are basically tired all the time and only sitting through one 
math class? No one is doing the math. If only 10 percent get into top 
schools, which require massive tuition and even more expense, then the 
other 60 percent spending money on private education wasted all that money 
and time and likely still managed to get into college. ﻿
comments.author: kris Sharp

comments.text:
In Australia getting into a university is the easiest thing ever. I 
auditioned for jazz school, got a good GPA in my first year of a music 
degree then transferred to a law degree. Life is unfair...﻿

comments.text:

This is awesome and it reminds of my medical school. When we finished our 
first anatomy quiz as 1st  years, we came out of anatomy lab and all the

comments.text:
Here in Ireland, the 3rd years and 6th years are getting ready to do the 
Junior and Leaving Cert exams in a few days (we just have secondary school, 
which is high school and middle school stuck together). Two weeks before 
them, they all go home and just study flat out.﻿
comments.author: Evelyn Hamilton

comments.text:
+Kyoko Kirigiri There is no 'middle school' and 'high school' in Ireland. 
They're both stuck together in one school(secondary school). In 3rd year, 
you do your Junior Cert, and in 6th year(think 17, 18 and 19 year olds) you 
do yor Leaving Cert, where you get points from each exam. Your total amount 
of points decides what you can do in college.
comments.author: Evelyn Hamilton

comments.text: I'm sorry...6th years?

comments.text:
I was just watching this and I suddenly remembered once that one of my 
friends had woke up at 4am to straighten her hair and it was raining that 
morning so when she got out of the school bus, her hair got soaked and I 
was laughing at her all day. I know it's totally off topic but it reminds 
me of this.
comments.author: Lola Star

comments.text:
You know what else screws you up more than teen pregnancy? Suicide.. Death, 
It's the finality of everything you are. This helps the mental & emotional 
torture needed to commit the act. Finland has the shortest known class 
sessions in the world, lasting 3-5 hours & maybe even shorter BUT they are 
the most highest graded in international test scores, world-wide standards. 
See the contrast? It is an evidence to how ridiculous this is. It being 
their culture doesn't make it any better.
comments.author: Abgef

comments.text:
It would be inhuman if you were a stranger to that culture and suddenly had 
to adapt to it, but generally speaking, support systems evolve in the 
classroom for well-adjusted students who raised in this culture. I'm not 
saying there aren't better ways of doing things. But their current system 
isn't all bad. South Korea has some of the lowest rates of teen pregnancy 
and juvenile crime in the world, both of which screw up your future a lot 
more than a bad test score.
comments.author: Lunay LeZarde

comments.text:
You're talking about me as if it's me who will be taking the exam? Tell 
me.. Am I to be held responsible if I may have helped create a culture of 
suicidal youths? What makes a person want to kill themselves? What do you 
think it does to a country when they make teenage drones who study 14 hours 
a day & then give them a one-shot on their future? Not to mention the 
parental expectations from these Asian parents.. It's almost inhuman, admit 
it.
comments.author: Abgef

comments.text:
Your argument cedes too much control to outside forces, when in reality 
it's ultimately up to you whether all that junk is going to define how you 
perform. I'm not saying that when the worst happens it's easy to shut it 
out and do what needs to get done. I'm saying it's possible, and like with 
any other skill, some are going to be better at it than others, and some 
won't need it at all. That's life.
comments.author: Lunay LeZarde

comments.text:
Nonsense.. It gives the assumption that people can never change & thus only 
gives one shot jackpot to everyone. How can you adapt to "different" 
situation when there's only this situation which can in fact ruin your 
life? Despite the fact that they study in school 14 hours a day.. that's 
not enough? It's that lack of consideration for the rest of their future 
that makes absolutely no sense. Too much is based on chance. No wonder 
Korean kids want to kill themselves.
comments.author: Abgef

comments.text:
Umm, I hate to break this to you, but handling pressure and adapting to 
different situations is a skill, too. Sorry to burst your bubble.
comments.author: Lunay LeZarde

comments.text:
It doesn't go for the U.S. I never took ANY college entrance exam in High 
School, but still got into a good university because of the ACT score I 
earned in my 30's. If the SAT score from your junior year in high school 
were the only thing that counted, I wouldn't have student loans to pay off, 
so...mixed blessing, I guess. I guess my core question is: Can you postpone 
this to a later year in Korea, or is there a stigma/prejudice attached to 
waiting a year or 10?
comments.author: Lunay LeZarde

comments.text:
If stuff happens in your personal life that affects your performance, you 
just have to work that much harder to make up for the crappy score. That's 
life, no matter where you go. I'm pretty sure if there were something 
medical going on, they'd let you postpone it, although it may depend on the 
school. Religious bows in Korea are not to people, but to shrines and 
idols. The point of either is acknowledgment and respect. Hope that answers 
your questions.
comments.author: Lunay LeZarde

comments.text:
I believe that you can take the SAT when ever you feel like. HOWEVER, no 
matter what, the SAT you take your third year of high school is the only 
one that counts. Even if you say took it your first year of high school and 
got a higher score than the one you took your third year, it is only the 
third year that counts. Some people take it early to get a feel for the 
test and to prepare themselves. This goes for the U.S., and I would guess 
the same for Korea but I'm not sure.
comments.author: xSakura8896

comments.text:
Every culture has their norms. Asian cultures bow to their elders, they bow 
out of respect, nothing to do with religion. Here, they are bowing to show 
respect to their seniors (important) and to wish them all the best. Asian 
people look at westerners who kiss on the cheek as a greeting in a weird 
light too. Same thing, people from other cultures do things differently 
that might feel weird to us. But it is your judgemental attitude and 
shallow view that makes the place a worse place.
comments.author: aznravenflame

comments.text:
I heard that most of students who are not 12th graders have to go to school 
like 2 hours later than normal because they might get louder and affect 
those people who are taking that crazy test... tats kinda crazy
comments.author: Yolo

comments.text: Well it's scary ....
comments.author: Pitchoo973

comments.text:
I took the ACT, not the SAT, and I did it in my 30's. Got a 24 without 
studying for it at all. That's 5 points higher than my wife, who took it 
back in high school, and she had a 4.0 GPA. That brings me to my serious 
question: Do you HAVE to take this test in your 3rd year of high school or 
can you put it off a year if you don't feel ready? I know Korean culture 
doesn't usually embrace that kind of individual self-assessment, but it 
would be nice if all that pressure could be a little less.
comments.author: Lunay LeZarde

comments.text:
You know if I had had crowds of people cheering me in when I took my SATs I 
probably would have done better
comments.author: Mara Joya

comments.text:
the bowing is the showing of respect. they probably did that to show 
respect towards the students who prepared so hard their last 3 years for 
this day and to wish them luck. i know that it may seem weird because you 
didnt exactly know what it was about but every culture is different so you 
could really learn to understand and respect it. im sure if someone said 
something offensive about something that the culture you are from does 
regularly, you would feel uncomfortable. and thats my case :/ thx

comments.text:
Back in my day we only commented once. Now we can comment as many times as

comments.author: Maya ThePanda

comments.text: I take sat in 8th and 12 th grade FML
comments.author: OneLove Phia

comments.text:
we weren't like this video but our city made a big deal about the schools 
with the best overall KCPE scores since it determined where the brightests 
students were. The news and media would eagerly await results and the 
following day would have a big congratualtions for the top school and go to 
that school and spotlight them.i always have respect for places that come 
together to sort of celebrate education since it helps foster ambitious 
students
comments.author: cbuz06

comments.text:
Back when i was in Kenya our schooling was a mixture of both. We had school 
for 7 hours, homework was strict if you get below 75% on three subjects you 
fail that year. and if you get below 75% on three tests you also fail that 
year.No calculators for math. our KCPE exams(high school entrance) and KCSE 
exams(SAT-like) could only be taken once. But unfortunately for me i moved 
to America for high school so i got a mediocre education. I always wonder 
if its the same now back home but i'm not sure
comments.author: cbuz06

comments.text:
On one hand i see Korea as very strict when it comes to studies. Studying 
for so many hours in a day and basically spending life in school then the 
entrance exam you can only take it once and thats it. At the same time it 
breeds exceptional students so there's a pro to that con. In America its a 
very lackadaisical education. School is about 6-7 hours(we thought that was 
long), SAT's can be done over and over, a 2.5 gpa can get into college.its 
good you get chances but people wont be ambitious
comments.author: cbuz06

comments.text:
Because the idea of one exam determining your whole life is utterly 
ridiculous and stupid. I truly feel sorry for them. This isn't education, 
this is manufacturing robots. I respect their culture, but don't fool 
yourself into thinking that it's the right way to do things.
comments.author: FreakoChu

comments.text:
when my father was young, they only took it once. now we can take it as

when my father was young, they only took it once. now we can take it as

comments.text:
My exchange students explained this ALL to me! They told me all about the 
"SKY" concept, the hard work, the studying for many years, the 
ONE-time-only exam that determines your future.....so hardcore, but 
probably so rewarding once it's done! I feel so proud of all the Korean 
students who completed the exam, scored well, and are on to bright futures!

i know how they feel, same happens in brazil. you only can take ENEM (our

comments.text: Why can't American and Canadian culture take school this seriously

comments.text: they use to do the same in America. back in the 70s-80s
comments.author: Sweetiegirl18

comments.text:
No. The university entrance exam takes place only once a year, so you have 
to wait for another year to re-take the exam for the failed subject.
comments.author: Albert Seo

comments.text:
Wait.. os like if they fail a subject or something, they cant "re-take" 
that subject or anything? Like their future is over? They cant improve 
grades or anything?

comments.text: I wish this happened when I took the SAT's

comments.text: its so sweet how supportive everyone is <#
comments.author: Istrawberrystarburst

comments.text:
Not really. You can take the exam again-same one- by repeating the 3rd Year 
called Jae-Su, or do a standardized entrance test called Gum-jeong-go-shi. 
However, there is a lot of competition, and those who fail the first time 
are looked unfavorably. Also, it is much harder than SAT with a lot 
competitors and small opening. Korean 3rd years pretty much get no life at 
all compared to say HSC or SAT students.
comments.author: John Kang

comments.text:
그니까 말이에요 ㅋㅋㅋㅋ 그저 저렇게 나와서 응원하는게 부럽다, 가족같다, 너무 귀엽다 라는 말만 하는데.... 현실을 알면...... 
ㅎ;
comments.author: toryjuicyprada

comments.text:
martina just said that as SAT but of course it is not the SAT we take. In 
korean it is called Su-Hak-Neung-Ryuk-gum-jung-si-hum. 수학능력검정시험. And the 
test includes Korean lang. English, science for some ppl, social studies 
for some ppl, math, extra language and additional options. The test lasts 
from 9 Am to 5 or 6 PM.
comments.author: toryjuicyprada

comments.text:
o you will regret that. I am telling you... THERE IS NO FUN GOING TO SCHOOL 
IN KOREA. Seriously there is no fun. you go there sit on the desk and the 
teachers come in and have lessons and you clean the classroom and in high 
school you also have to stay at school and study until 9 o clock mostly 
mandatory. DO You Want That Life?????? NOOOOOOOOO O_o
comments.author: toryjuicyprada

comments.text:
percentage of students actually do that cuz going to a top university is 
very important 4 u r life in korea. U get judged by which college u r from. 
Some people actually study years n years after high s. graduation 2 go 2 
the top college. They are called Jae-Su-Seng. I heard about a guy who 
studied for 8 extra years 2 go 2 the number 1 univ. Also, that day is so 
significant that any planes or military purpose flying objects are not 
allowed to depart during certain period of the test.
comments.author: toryjuicyprada

comments.text:
That day is considered one of the most important day in korea. that is the 
day your future is determined by whether you go to a good college or not. 
That is the only entrance exam day in a year and that day is what every 
student from elementary school prepare for until the 3rd year of high 
school. Literally no one fails the test, but if you get low rank grade, 
honestly it's bad for applying to top colleges. So those people would go to 
cram school for another year to get higher rank. And much
comments.author: toryjuicyprada

comments.text: So 1 question: What happens if one fail their exam?
comments.author: Thanh Nguyen

comments.text:
?? South Korean students can freely hate school. Plus, cheering on the exam 
day is not mandatory at all. Most of the students enjoy their free time. No 
one forces these students to do this. (you know it's SOUTH korea, not north 
lol) They do this for fun actually.. They don't care much about 'cheering' 
itself. They just enjoy the mood and singing and stuff
comments.author: Yonny Lee

comments.text:
it's also interesting to understand how big of a deal this actually is in 
Korean culture. The week of the test, You'll see famous celebrities wishing 
high school students good luck on TV and police cars patrol that morning 
all over Korea to find and help kids that missed the bus or whatever and 
are running late and pick them up and take them to the exam site with the 
police sirens on. Although I'm not envious of the test and the pressure it 
brings with it, I do really love the sense of community
comments.author: rbkjinski

comments.text: Oh I wish so badly that I went to school in Korea
comments.author: mmbestfriends

comments.text:
ive been kinda confused about this: the SAT that korean ppl take how is it 
different from the ones we take in America? (because it can't be the same 
right??? O_O)

I almost cried when they did the bow.. so different from my country..

comments.text: Idk why but Martina's bowing fail just cracked me up sooo much xD ahahaha

comments.text:
this makes me kind of resent the school system of korea. they're producing 
hardworking, dedicated children, but what about creativity and second

portrayal of a students abilities. they are definately more smart and

comments.text: 01:23 Wahaha Martina you're a cool teacher

and these kind of exams not end after the Korean SAT.lots of graduates and

comments.text:
for korean high school 3rd students it is one shot that seize everything 
they ever wanted It's all. at that time. if he/she fail, lots of students 
would prepare for next year's chance and.. next. next... They said that 
taking the college entrance exam three times was a must to get into good 
colleges in my day. actually lots of high scored students are 2 times or 3 
times and so on. they're called in korea N수생(N represent 'N'umber 
especailly n>=3)

comments.text: awww they're so sweet! omg no one supported me when i had exams going on T_T

am i the only one who doesn't think "aww they're so supporting :') wish it

comments.text: I wish my frined would have done something like this for me
comments.author: sakurakou2009

comments.text: This is really touching :')
comments.author: RachelK

comments.text:
People don't do this in America because in America when you take your SAT 
you have the ability to take it over and over again depending on whether 
you had a bad day or didn't study hard enough. In Korea, you have one shot. 
If you do poorly, that's it. There's no other exam date to redeem yourself.
comments.author: dubulge

comments.text:
This is so cool! I wonder if we were all supportive like this and had a 
more "family" mentality if more of our kids would go to college and maybe 
there would be less bullying?
comments.author: TheSilverGarnet
